additives.name: Curcuma (turmeric)
additives.warnings: Safe in recommended doses. High doses should not be taken by people with gallstones, obstructive jaundice, acute bilious colic or toxic liver disorders.
additives.foods: Fats and oils, curry, processed cheese and fish fingers.
additives.details: Orange-yellow colouring extracted from the rhizomes of the turmeric plant.

additives.name: Riboflavin (Vitamin B2)
additives.foods: Sauces, processed cheese and foods with added vitamins such as bread.
additives.details: Riboflavin is also known as vitamin B2. Obtained by fermenting yeast or synthesised artificially.

additives.name: Riboflavin-5'-Phosphate
additives.foods: Found in many foods for babies and young children as well as jams, milk products and sweets and sugar products.
additives.details: Consists mainly of the monosodium salt of the 5'-monophosphate ester of riboflavin dihydrate obtained from chemical action on E101 Riboflavin. It is rapidly turned to free riboflavin after ingestion.

additives.name: Tartrazine (FD&C Yellow 5)
additives.warnings: Provokes asthma attacks, urticaria in children, linked to thyroid tumors, chromosomal damage. Tartrazine appears to cause the most allergic and/or intolerance reactions of all the azo dyes, particularly amongst those with an aspirin intolerance and asthmatics. Other reactions can include migraine, blurred vision, itching, rhinitis and purple skin patches. In conjunction with E210 tartrazine appears to create an over-activity in children.
additives.foods: Fruit squash, fruit cordial, coloured fizzy drinks, instant puddings, cake mixes, custard powder, soups, sauces, ice cream, ice lollies, sweets, chewing gum, marzipan, jam, jelly, marmalade, mustard, yoghurt and many convenience foods together with glycerine, lemon and honey products.
additives.details: Yellow coloured synthetic azo colour.

additives.name: Chrysoine resorcinol
additives.status: Forbidden (Banned in Europe since 1984. In the US, it was banned in 1988.)

additives.name: Quinoline Yellow
additives.warnings: Cause dermatitis. Not recommended for consumption by children. HACSG recommends to avoid it.
additives.status: Not permitted. Banned in Australia, Japan, Norway and US.
additives.foods: Smoked fish, ice cream, scotch eggs and smoked haddock. Used in lipsticks hair products, colognes; also in a wide range of medications;
additives.details: The disodium salt of disulphonic acid. A synthetic 'coal tar' dye.

additives.name: Fast Yellow AB
additives.details: An azo dye.

additives.name: Riboflavin-5-Sodium Phosphate
additives.details: Similar to E101a.

additives.name: Yellow 2G
additives.warnings: People who suffer Asthma may also show an allergic reaction to it. HACSG recommends to avoid it.
additives.status: Banned in Austria, Japan, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland and US.
additives.details: It has the appearance of a yellow powder, soluble in water. It is a synthetic coal tar and yellow azo dye.

additives.name: Sunset Yellow FCF (Orange Yellow S)
additives.warnings: Urticaria (hives), rhinitis (runny nose), nasal congestion, allergies, hyperactivity, kidney tumors, chromosomal damage, abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, indigestion, distaste for food; increased incidence of tumors in animals. It appears to cause allergic and/or intolerance reactions, particularly amongst those with an aspirin intolerance. Not recommended for consumption by children. HACSG recommends to avoid it.
additives.status: Banned in Finland, Norway & the UK (voluntarily). Products in the EU require warnings and is evaluating a phase-out.
additives.foods: Orange squash, orange jelly, marzipan, Swiss roll, apricot jam, citrus marmalade, lemon curd, sweets, hot chocolate mix and packet soups, breadcrumbs, cheese sauce, ice cream, canned fish, and many medications.
additives.details: A synthetic 'coal tar' and azo yellow dye used in fermented foods which must be heat treated.

additives.name: Orange GGN
additives.details: Orange GGN, also known as alpha-naphthol orange, is a food dye.

additives.name: Cochineal; Carminic acid; Carmines
additives.warnings: May cause allergic reactions. Not recommended for consumption by children. HACSG recommends to avoid it.
additives.foods: Alcoholic drinks, bakery products and toppings, biscuits, desserts, drinks, icings, pie fillings, some varieties of cheddar cheese, sauces and sweets.
additives.details: An expensive red colouring, not suitable for vegetarians as it is extracted from the crushed carcasses of the female Dactylopius coccus, a cactus-feeding scale insect, which are killed by either immersion in hot water or by exposure to sunlight, steam, or the heat of an oven.

additives.name: Citrus Red 2
additives.warnings: Carcinogen
additives.details: It is an orange to yellow solid or a dark red powder with a melting point of 156 Â°C.

additives.name: Carmoisine; Azorubine
additives.warnings: It appears to cause allergic and/or intolerance reactions, particularly amongst those with an aspirin intolerance. Other reactions can include a rash similar to nettle rash and water retention. Not recommended for consumption by children. HACSG recommends to avoid it.
additives.status: Undergoing a voluntary phase-out in the UK, currently banned in Canada, Japan, Norway, USA & Sweden. EU currently evaluating health risks.
additives.foods: Foods which must be heat treated after fermentation. Also found in blancmange, marzipan, Swiss roll, jams and preserves, sweets, brown sauce, flavoured yogurts, packet soups, jellies, breadcrumbs and cheesecake mixes.
additives.details: Red coloured synthetic azo colour.

additives.name: Amaranth; FD&C Red 2
additives.warnings: It appears to cause allergic and/or intolerance reactions, similar to nettle rash, particularly amongst those with an aspirin intolerance or asthmatics. can provoke asthma, eczema and hyperactivity; it caused birth defects and foetal deaths in some animal tests, possibly also cancer. Not recommended for consumption by children.
additives.status: Forbidden (Banned in the United States in 1976. Several countries still use it!)
additives.foods: Ice creams, gravy granules, jams, jelly, tinned fruit pie fillings and prawns and packeted cake mixes, soups and trifles.
additives.details: Derived from the small herbaceous plant of the same name. A purplish-red (blackcurrant) synthetic coal tar or azo dye.

additives.name: Ponceau 4R; Cochineal Red A, Brilliant Scarlet 4R
additives.warnings: It appears to cause allergic and/or intolerance reactions particularly amongst those with an aspirin intolerance or asthmatics. Carcinogen in animals. Not recommended for consumption by children. HACSG recommends to avoid it.
additives.foods: Sessert toppings, jelly, salami, seafood dressings, tinned strawberries and fruit pie fillings and packeted cake mixes, cheesecakes, soups and trifles.
additives.details: A red synthetic coal tar or azo dye.

additives.name: Ponceau SX; Scarlet GN
additives.details: A red azo dye.

additives.name: Ponceau 6R
additives.details: A red azo dye. It is soluble in water and slightly soluble in ethanol.

additives.name: Erythrosine (FD&C Red 3)
additives.warnings: Because food processing at temperatures above 200Â°c partly degrades Erythrosine, releasing iodide, there are fears that it could affect thyroid activity, can increase thyroid hormone levels and lead to hyperthyroidism, was shown to cause thyroid cancer in rats in a study in 1990. It is toxic to some strains of yeast cells and is also implicated in phototoxicity (a sensitivity to light). Not recommended for consumption by children. HACSG recommends to avoid it.
additives.foods: Cocktail, glacÃ© and tinned cherries, canned fruit, custard mix, sweets, bakery, snack foods, biscuits, chocolate, dressed crab, garlic sausage, luncheon meat, salmon spread, patÃ©, scotch eggs, stuffed olives and packet trifle mix. It is also used to reveal plaque in dental disclosing tablets.
additives.details: A cherry-pink/red synthetic coal tar dye.

additives.name: Red 2G
additives.warnings: Concerns that it can interfere with blood haemoglobin. Not recommended for consumption by children.
additives.foods: Meat products and sausages but can also be found in jams and drinks.
additives.details: A red synthetic coal tar or azo dye.

additives.name: Allura Red AC (FD&C Red 40)
additives.warnings: May have slightly less allergy/intolerance reaction by aspirin intolerant people and asthmatics than most of the azo dyes, although those with skin sensitivities should be careful. Allura red has also been connected with cancer in mice. Not recommended for consumption by children.
additives.status: Permitted in the US and by the EU (Banned in Denmark, Belgium, France, Switzerland & Sweden. Undergoing a voluntary phase out in the UK.)
additives.foods: Sweets, drinks and condiments, medications and cosmetics.
additives.details: A red synthetic azo dye introduced in the early eighties to replace Amaranth, E123, in USA where E123 is prohibited.

additives.name: Indanthrene blue RS
additives.details: Indanthrene Blue RS was patented in 1901 by Rene Bohn as the first anthraquinone vat dye, one of the dyes with very good fastness to light and washing. It is used to dye unmordanted cotton and as a pigment in quality paints and enamels.

additives.name: Patent Blue V
additives.warnings: Best avoided by people with allergy reactions as it can cause skin sensitivity, a rash similar to nettle rash, itching, nausea, low blood pressure, tremors and breathing problems.
additives.status: Dangerous (Banned in Australia, USA and Norway.)
additives.foods: Not widely used but can be found in Scotch eggs and is used diagnostically to colour lymph vessels.
additives.details: A dark bluish-violet synthetic coal tar dye.

additives.name: Indigo carmine; FD&C Blue 2
additives.warnings: People with allergies should avoid it. May cause nausea, vomiting, high blood pressure, skin rashes, breathing problems and other allergic reactions.
additives.foods: Commonly added to tablets and capsules; also used in ice cream, sweets, baked goods, confectionery, biscuits. It is also used diagnostically to check for coloured urine in kidney function tests.
additives.details: A blue synthetic coal tar dye, normally produced by a synthesis of indoxyl by fusion of sodium phenylglycinate in a mixture of caustic soda and sodamide.

additives.name: Brilliant Blue FCF (FD&C Blue 1)
additives.warnings: Not recommended for consumption by children. HACSG recommends to avoid it.
additives.status: Banned in Austria, Belgium, Denmark, France, Germany, Greece, Italy, Norway, Spain, Sweden and Switzerland.
additives.foods: Can be found in tinned processed peas, dairy products, sweets and drinks.
additives.details: A blue synthetic coal tar dye often used in conjunction with E102, Tartrazine, to produce various shades of green.

additives.name: Chlorophylls and chlorophyllins
additives.warnings: Has no maximum recommended daily intake and is not subject to any prohibitions.
additives.foods: Used for dyeing waxes and oils, used in medicines and cosmetics eg in chewing gum, fats and oils, ice cream, soaps, soups, sweets and, obviously, green vegetables.
additives.details: A fairly unstable dye, which tends to fade easily.

additives.name: Copper complexes of chlorophylls and chlorophyllins
additives.warnings: No adverse effects are known.
additives.foods: Found in some types of cheese, chewing gum, ice cream, Parsley sauce, soups and green vegetables and fruits preserved in liquids.
additives.details: Derived from Chlorophyll, E140, by substitution of copper for the magnesium, which increases stability.

additives.name: Green S
additives.warnings: Known to cause hyperactivity, asthma, uticaria, and insomnia. HACSG recommends to avoid it.
additives.status: Unpermitted (Banned in Canada, Finland, Japan, Norway, Sweden and the US.)
additives.foods: Desserts, gravy granules, ice cream, mint sauce, sweets, packet breadcrumbs, cake mixes and tinned peas.
additives.details: A green synthetic coal tar dye.

additives.name: Fast Green FCF (FD&C Green 3)
additives.warnings: Found to have Tumorigenic effects in experimental animals, as well as Mutagenic effects in both experimental animals and humans. It furthermore risks irritation of eyes, skin, digestive tract, and respiratory tract in its undiluted form.
additives.foods: It can be used for tinned green peas and other vegetables, jellies, sauces, fish, desserts, and dry bakery mixes at level of up to 100 mg/kg.
additives.details: A sea green triarylmethane food dye.

additives.name: Vegetable carbon
additives.warnings: Suspected as a carcinogenic agent. Vegetarians should note that it can be of animal origin.
additives.status: Banned in USA. Still used in Australia.
additives.foods: Concentrated fruit juices, jams, jellies and liquorice.
additives.details: It is normally derived from burnt vegetable matter.

additives.name: Brown FK
additives.foods: Found mainly in kippers and smoked mackerel but also occasionally in cooked hams and crisps.
additives.details: A highly suspect brown mixture of six synthetic azo dyes together with other colourings and sodium chloride and/or sodium sulphate.

additives.name: Brown HT
additives.warnings: Bad reactions in asthmatics and people allergic to aspirin, also known to induce skin sensitivity. HACSG recommends to avoid it.
additives.status: Banned in Australia, Austria, Belgium, Denmark, France, Germany, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland and USA.
additives.details: A brown synthetic 'coal tar' and azo dye found mainly in chocolate flavour cakes.

additives.name: Carotenes
additives.foods: Butter and soft margarines, coffee sponge cakes, milk products and soft drinks.
additives.details: Orange or yellow plant pigments. Converts to vitamin A in the body.

additives.name: Annatto; Bixin; Norbixin
additives.warnings: Known to cause urticaria (nettle rash), the HACSG recommends to avoid it.
additives.foods: Cheese, coleslaw, crisps, custard, fish fingers, flavoured instant mashed potato, fruit and cream fillings and toppings, frying oil, ice cream and lollies, icings, liqueurs, low calorie spreads, margarine, meat balls, salad cream and mayonnaise, smoked fish, soft drinks, sponge cakes and puddings, steak and kidney pie pastry and yoghurt.
additives.details: A yellow, peach or red vegetable dye obtained from the seed coat of the fruit of the Annatto tree, Bixa orellana.

additives.name: Paprika extract; Capsanthian; Capsorubin
additives.foods: Used widely in poultry feed to deepen the colour of egg yolks (see also E161b) it can also be found in cheese slices and chicken pies.
additives.details: An orange to red color extracted from the fruit pod and seeds of the red pepper, Capsicum annuum.

additives.name: Lycopene
additives.details: A red colour extracted from tomatoes and pink grapefruit.

additives.name: Beta-apo-8' carotenal (C30)
additives.details: Orange-yellow synthetic colour.

additives.name: Ethyl ester of beta-apo-8'-carotenic acid (C 30)
additives.details: Synthesised version of a naturally-occuring orange colour.

additives.name: Lutein
additives.details: Yellow-red colour extracted from plants. related to the carotenes (E160a). Can be added to chicken feed to enhance colour of egg yolk.

additives.name: Canthaxanthin
additives.warnings: Found to accumulate on the retina, having a detrimental effect on eyesight.
additives.foods: Used in such products as chicken in breadcrumbs, fish fingers, mallow biscuits, pickles and preserves, sauces and sweets it is also fed to laying hens to make to colour egg yolks.
additives.details: Yellow color, historically it was prepared from shrimp waste or flaming feathers. Synthetic cantaxanthin is cheaper and has higher purity.

additives.name: Beetroot Red; Betanin
additives.foods: Bacon burgers, desserts, ice cream, jams, jellies, liquorice, oxtail soup, sauces and sweets.
additives.details: purple color derived from beets

additives.name: Anthocyanins
additives.foods: Black cherry yoghurt, dairy products, glacÃ© cherries, ice cream, jellies, pickles, soft drinks, tomato, carrot or vegetable soups and sweets.
additives.details: Red-blue colours that are obtained from a variety of plant sources, especially grapes and red cabbage.

additives.name: Calcium carbonate
additives.warnings: Toxic at 'high doses'.
additives.foods: Biscuits, bread, cakes, ice cream, sweets, vitamin and other tablets and to firm canned fruit and vegetables, it is sometimes used for to deacidify wine. Also used in toothpastes, white paint and cleaning powders.
additives.details: Chalk. Used as a white colour. As it is an alkali, it may be also used to regulate the pH of foods such as canned fruits and vegetables.

additives.name: Titanium dioxide
additives.warnings: Safe but pollutes waterways.
additives.foods: Tablets and capsules, cottage and Mozzarella cheeses, horseradish cream and sauces, lemon curd, toothpaste, and white paint, also in sweets.
additives.details: White, mineral-based colour.

additives.name: Iron oxides and hydroxides
additives.warnings: Toxic at 'high doses'.
additives.foods: Cake and dessert mixes, meat paste, salmon and shrimp paste.
additives.details: Naturally occurring pigments of iron, which can be yellow, red, orange, brown or black in colour.

additives.name: Aluminium
additives.warnings: Potentially toxic.
additives.details: Silvery-white metal smelted from the ore, Bauxite.

additives.name: Silver
additives.warnings: Long, regular consumption can lead to kidney damage and a blue-grey discoloration of the eyes, nose and nasal septum, throat and skin.
additives.details: Silver coloured surface coating.

additives.name: Gold
additives.warnings: Harmless, but best avoided.
additives.details: Gold coloured surface coating.

additives.name: Pigment Rubine; Lithol Rubine BK
additives.warnings: People who suffer from asthma, rhinitis or the skin disease urticaria may find their symptoms become worse following consumption of azo dyes.
additives.details: Red synthetic colour.

additives.name: Tannin
additives.details: Derived from the nutgalls and twigs of oak trees; occurs naturally in tea.

additives.name: Sorbic acid
additives.warnings: A possible skin irritant.
additives.foods: Drinks, dairy products, fish, seafood, fat-based products, baked foods and confectionery.
additives.details: Either obtained from berries or synthesised from ketene.

additives.name: Potassium sorbate
additives.details: Helps to prevent the growth of microbes on food. Related to Sorbic acid (E200). Effective in a wide range of foods. Does not have any flavour or taste.

additives.name: Calcium sorbate
additives.details: Helps to prevent the growth of microbes on food. Related to Sorbic acid (E200). Effective in a wide range of foods. Does not have any flavour or taste.

additives.name: Benzoic acid
additives.warnings: Can cause asthma, hyperactivity in children. The HACSG recommends to avoid it.
additives.foods: Beer, fruit juice, yoghurt, soft drinks.
additives.details: Prevents the growth of microbes in acidic environments.

additives.name: Sodium benzoate
additives.warnings: Known to causes nettle rash and aggravate asthma. HACSG recommends to avoid it.
additives.foods: Beer, fruit juice, yoghurt, soft drinks.
additives.details: Prevents the growth of microbes in acidic environments.

additives.name: Potassium benzoate
additives.warnings: People with a history of allergies may show allergic reactions.
additives.details: Prevents the growth of microbes in acidic environments.

additives.name: Potassium benzoate
additives.warnings: People with a history of allergies may show allergic reactions.
additives.details: Prevents the growth of microbes in acidic environments.

additives.name: Calcium benzoate
additives.warnings: See E212.
additives.details: Prevents the growth of microbes.

additives.name: Ethyl p-hydroxybenzoate
additives.warnings: Avoid it, banned in some countries.
additives.status: Dangerous (Not permitted in France and Australia.)
additives.details: Prevents the growth of microbes.

additives.name: Sodium ethyl p-hydroxybenzoate
additives.warnings: Avoid it, banned in some countries.
additives.details: Prevents the growth of microbes.

additives.name: Propyl p-hydroxybenzoate
additives.warnings: Possible contact allergen.
additives.foods: Beer, sauces, fruit juices, salad cream.
additives.details: Prevents the growth of microbes.

additives.name: Sodium propyl p-hydroxybenzoate
additives.warnings: Avoid it, banned in some countries.
additives.details: Prevents the growth of microbes.

additives.name: Methyl p-hydroxybenzoate
additives.warnings: Allergic reactions possible, mainly affecting the skin.
additives.status: Not permitted in France and Australia.
additives.details: Prevents the growth of microbes.

additives.name: Sodium methyl p-hydroxybenzoate
additives.warnings: Avoid it, banned in some countries.
additives.status: Not permitted in France and Australia.
additives.details: Prevents the growth of microbes, especially fungi.

additives.name: Sulphur dioxide
additives.warnings: Known to provoke asthma attacks, difficult to metabolize, destroys vitamin B1. The HACSG recommends to avoid it.
additives.foods: Fruit juices, beers, wines, dried vegetables, sausages.
additives.details: One of the earliest preservatives known to humans. Sulfur dioxide has been used for centuries to prevent the growth of bacteria in beers and wines. It can be used in many situations to prevent microbial growth.

additives.name: Sodium sulphite
additives.warnings: Dangerous additives for health. See 220.
additives.details: Similar in action to sulfur dioxide. Sodium sulfite is regularly used in brewing and wine making to sterilise equipment. In foods it prevents microbial growth (especially salmonella). It also prevents the discolouration of meat, peeled apples and potatoes.

additives.name: Sodium hydrogen sulphite
additives.warnings: Dangerous additives for health. See 220.
additives.foods: Fruit juices, beers, wines, frozen chips.
additives.details: Used to prevent the growth of bacteria in beers and wines. It can be used in many situations to prevent microbial growth.

additives.name: Sodium metabisuiphite
additives.warnings: Dangerous additives for health. See 220.
additives.details: Prevents microbial growth.

additives.name: Potassium metabisulphite
additives.warnings: Dangerous additives for health. See 220.
additives.details: Prevents microbial growth, especially used in home brewing and wine making.

additives.name: Calcium sulphite
additives.warnings: Avoid it, banned in some countries.
additives.details: Used in brewing and wine making to sterilise equipment and prevent microbial growth.

additives.name: Calcium hydrogen sulphite
additives.warnings: Avoid it, banned in some countries.
additives.details: Used in brewing and wine making to sterilise equipment and prevent microbial growth.

additives.name: Potassium hydrogen sulphite
additives.warnings: Dangerous additives for health. See 220.
additives.details: Slows the growth of food-spoiling micro-organisms.

additives.name: Biphenyl; diphenyl
additives.warnings: Avoid it, banned in some countries.
additives.details: Prevents the growth of moulds such as Penicillium sp. on the surface of fruits.

additives.name: Orthophenyl phenol
additives.warnings: Avoid it, banned in some countries.
additives.details: Prevents the growth of microbes. Applied to the surface of fruits or their wrappings.

additives.name: Sodium orthophenyl phenol
additives.warnings: Avoid it, banned in some countries. See 231.
additives.details: Prevents the growth of microbes. Applied to the surface of fruits or their wrappings.

additives.name: Thiabendazole
additives.warnings: Avoid it, banned in some countries.
additives.foods: Citrus fruits, apples, pears, potatoes, bananas, mushrooms, meat, milk.

additives.name: Nisin
additives.details: Prevents the growth of microbes.

additives.name: Natamycin
additives.warnings: Can cause nausea, vomiting, anorexia, diarrhea and skin irritation.
additives.details: Antimicrobial that prevents the growth of fungi in cheeses.

additives.name: Formic acid
additives.warnings: Avoid it, banned in some countries.

additives.name: Sodium formate
additives.warnings: Avoid it, banned in some countries.

additives.name: Calcium formate
additives.warnings: Avoid it, banned in some countries.

additives.name: Hexamethylene tetramine
additives.warnings: Avoid it, banned in some countries.
additives.details: Prevents the growth of microbes.

additives.name: Dimethyl dicarbonate
additives.details: Prevents the growth of microbes.

additives.name: Potassium nitrite
additives.warnings: Dangerous additives for health. May cause dizzynesss, headaches, difficult breathing,potential carcinogen.
additives.details: Prevents the growth of the botulism bacteria (Clostridium botulinum) in meat.

additives.name: Sodium nitrite
additives.warnings: Potentially carcinogenic, restricted in many countries. The HACSG recommends to avoid it (see 249).
additives.details: Prevents the growth of the botulism bacteria (Clostridium botulinum) in meat.

additives.name: Sodium nitrate
additives.warnings: Dangerous additives for health
additives.details: Reduces the growth of toxic micro-organisms in meat.

additives.name: Potassium nitrate
additives.warnings: May provoke hyperactivity and other adverse reactions; potentially carcinogenic; restricted in many countries (see 249).
additives.details: Prevents the growth of the bacteria that causes botulism (Clostridium botulinum).

additives.name: Acetic acid
additives.foods: Pickles, bread, salad cream, processed cheese, beer.
additives.details: Reduces the growth of bacteria and can also be used to regulate the acidity of foods.

additives.name: Potassium acetate
additives.warnings: Should be avoided by people with impaired kidney function.
additives.details: Food acid.

additives.name: Sodium acetate; Sodium diacetate
additives.details: Food acid, acidity regulator.

additives.name: Calcium acetate
additives.details: Calcium salt of acetic acid. Reduces the growth of fungi in bread.

additives.name: Ammonium acetate
additives.warnings: Can cause nausea and vomiting.

additives.name: Lactic acid
additives.warnings: Difficult for babies to metabolize.
additives.foods: Sweets, dressings, soft drinks (sometimes beer) infant formulas and confectionary.
additives.details: Made by bacterial fermentation on sugar waste (molasses).

additives.name: Propionic acid
additives.warnings: Dangerous additives for health
additives.details: Naturally-occuring fatty acid. Reduces the growth of fungi.

additives.name: Sodium propionate
additives.warnings: Linked to migraines.
additives.details: Prevents the growth of bacteria in breads.

additives.name: Calcium propionate
additives.warnings: Linked to migraines.
additives.details: Prevents the growth of bacteria in breads.

additives.name: Potassium propionate
additives.warnings: Linked to migraines.
additives.details: Prevents the growth of bacteria in breads.

additives.name: Boric acid
additives.warnings: Ingestion is harmful and may be fatal. Harmful by inhalation. An irritant. May cause congenital malformation in the foetus. Laboratory tests with animals suggest this material may cause reproductive disorders.
additives.details: Used on the surface to prevent spoilage.

additives.name: Sodium tetraborate; borax
additives.warnings: Possible risk that this may cause reproductive disorders, based on tests with laboratory animals. Eye and skin irritant. Harmful by ingestion. May be harmful by inhalation.
additives.details: Used on the surface to prevent spoilage.

additives.name: Carbon dioxide
additives.warnings: May increase the effect of alcohol.
additives.details: Gas. Propellant, coolant, derived from lime manufacture.

additives.name: Malic acid
additives.warnings: Infants and young children should avoid it.
additives.foods: Carbonated drinks, tinned soups, frozen chips, processed peas.
additives.details: Derived from fruit or synthetic.

additives.name: Fumaric acid
additives.details: Naturally occuring compound. Derived from plants of the genus Fumaria.

additives.name: Ascorbic acid
additives.foods: Beers, cut fruits, jams, dried potato.
additives.details: Helps to prevent cut and pulped foods from going brown by preventing the oxidation reactions that cause the discolouration. Can be added to foods, such as potato, to replace vitamin C lost in processing.

additives.name: Sodium ascorbate
additives.details: Helps to prevent oxidation reactions that can discolour foods. Sodium salt of vitamin C.

additives.name: Calcium ascorbate
additives.details: Helps to prevent oxidation reactions that can discolour foods. Vitamin C, may increase the formation of calcium oxalate stones.

additives.name: Potassium ascorbate
additives.details: Potassium salt of vitamin C.

additives.name: Fatty acid esters of ascorbic acid
additives.details: Helps to prevent oxidation reactions that can discolour foods.

additives.name: Tocopherols
additives.warnings: May come from Genetically Modified sources.
additives.foods: Found in most foods, it is abundant in, amongst other things, whole grain cereals, corn and cottonseed oils, egg yolks, meat and milk.
additives.details: Vitamin E, known as the anti-sterility vitamin. Reduces oxidation of fatty acids and some vitamins. Commercially it can be extracted, by distillation in a vacuum, from cottonseed, maize, rice germ, soya been oil, wheat germ, or green leaves.

additives.name: Alpha-tocopherol
additives.warnings: May come from Genetically Modified sources.
additives.details: Vitamin E, known as the anti-sterility vitamin. Reduces oxidation of fatty acids and some vitamins. Commercially it can be extracted, by distillation in a vacuum, from cottonseed, maize, rice germ, soya been oil, wheat germ, or green leaves.

additives.name: Gamma-tocopherol
additives.warnings: May come from Genetically Modified sources.
additives.foods: Found in most foods, it is abundant in, amongst other things, whole grain cereals, corn and cottonseed oils, egg yolks, meat and milk.
additives.details: Vitamin E, known as the anti-sterility vitamin. E308 is an antioxidant for polyunsaturated fatty acids as well as a vitamin.

additives.name: Delta-tocopherol
additives.warnings: May come from Genetically Modified sources.

additives.name: Calcium 5'-ribonucleotides

additives.details: Similar to the molecules that make up DNA.

additives.name: Disodium 5'-ribonucleotides
additives.warnings: May be associated with itchy skin rashes up to 30 hours after ingestion. Avoid it, banned in some countries.
additives.details: Similar to the molecules that make up DNA.

additives.name: Maltol
additives.details: Derived from the bark of larch trees, pine needles, chicory wood, oils and roasted malt; it may be produced synthetically.

additives.name: Ethyl maltol
additives.details: Derived from maltol.

additives.name: Glycine and its sodium salt
additives.foods: May be used in any food.
additives.details: Naturally-occuring amino acid.

additives.name: Zinc acetate
additives.details: Zinc salt of acetic acid. Acts as a breth-freshener.

additives.name: Spiramycins
additives.foods: Dairy, meat, egg-products. Only allowed with special permission.
additives.details: Spiramycins are a class of antibiotics, produced by the mould Streptomyces ambofaciens.

additives.name: Tylosin
additives.foods: Dairy, meat, egg-products. Only allowed with special permission.
additives.details: Tylosin is an antibiotic, produced by the mould Streptomyces fradiae.

additives.name: Dimethylpolysiloxane
additives.foods: Jams, soft drinks, soups, brewing process.
additives.details: Silicone based. Helps to prevent powders from clumping together and becoming difficult to pour.

additives.name: Beeswax
additives.warnings: Occasionally causes allergic reactions.
additives.foods: Cakes and confectionery. Used to wax fruit.
additives.details: Purified from honey-bee hives. Made by bees, but does not contain insects.

additives.name: Candelilla wax
additives.details: Glazing agents help to give the food an appealing appearance.

additives.name: Carnauba wax
additives.warnings: Occasionally causes allergic reactions.
additives.foods: Chocolate confectionery. Used in cosmetics and inks, and to wax fruit.
additives.details: Derived from a South American palm.

additives.name: Shellac
additives.warnings: Occasionally causes irritations of the skin.
additives.details: Obtained from a resin produced by 'lac' insects and scale insects.

additives.name: Microcrystalline wax
additives.warnings: May be a link to bowel cancer.
additives.details: Synthetically-produced waxes.

additives.name: Refined microcrystalline wax
additives.warnings: Avoid it, banned in some countries.

additives.name: Montan acid esters
additives.details: Glazing agents help to give the food an appealing appearance.

additives.name: Lanolin
additives.details: Derived from sheep wool.

additives.name: Oxidised polyethylene wax
additives.details: Glazing agents help to give the food an appealing appearance.

additives.name: L-cysteine

additives.name: L-Cystin
additives.details: See E920.

additives.name: Potassium bromate
additives.warnings: Can cause nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, pain.

additives.name: Chlorine
additives.warnings: Destroys nutrients, carcinogen, in some areas tap water is contaminated with it, to make it 'safer' to drink.

additives.name: Chlorine dioxide
additives.warnings: See E925.

additives.name: Carbamide
additives.warnings: Avoid it, banned in some countries.
additives.details: Used in cakes to improve the flour during baking conditions.

additives.name: Benzoyl peroxide
additives.warnings: Asthmatics and people with a history of allergies must beware.

additives.name: Nitrogen
additives.details: Used in freezing and vacuum packing.

additives.name: Nitrous oxide
additives.warnings: Safe in small quantities

additives.name: Argon

additives.warnings: Seems quite safe in small quantities.

additives.name: Propane

additives.name: Oxygen
additives.details: Atmospheric gas.

additives.details: Gas

additives.name: Acesulphane potassium
additives.foods: Sweeteners, diet drinks, desserts, baked foods and puddings.
additives.details: Artificial sweetener discovered in 1967. It is approximately 200 times sweeter than sucrose and used in many low-calorie products.

additives.name: Aspartame
additives.warnings: Adverse effects, migraine headaches.
additives.foods: Sweeteners, diet drinks, desserts, baked foods and puddings.
additives.details: Artificial sweetener which is composed of aspartic acid and the methyl ester of phenylalanine (both amino acids). Used as a low-calorie sweetener in thousands of different products.

additives.name: Cyclamic acid and its Na and Ca salts
additives.warnings: Migraines, can be carcinogenic.
additives.status: Banned in the US and UK.
additives.details: Artificial sweetener that is approximately 30 times sweeter than sucrose (table sugar).

additives.name: lsomalt
additives.details: Derived from naturally-occuring sugars.

additives.name: Saccharin and its Na, K and Ca salts
additives.warnings: May be hazardous to your health, determined to cause cancer in laboratory animals.
additives.details: One of the first artificial sweeteners.

additives.name: Sucralose
additives.foods: Used in foods as a sugar replacement.
additives.details: Derived from sugar (sucrose) but modified so that it is not absorbed into the body. Used as a low calorie sweetener and substitute for sugar.

additives.name: Thaumatin
additives.foods: Used to sweeten wines, bread and fruit.
additives.details: Plant protein extracted from a fruit native to West Africa.

additives.name: Neohesperidine DC
additives.details: Plant material extracted and purified from grapefruit skin.

additives.name: Maltitol; Maltitol syrup
additives.details: Derived from naturally-occuring sugars.

additives.name: Lactitol
additives.details: Derived from naturally-occuring sugars.

additives.name: Xylitol
additives.details: Derived from naturally-occuring sugars.

additives.name: Quillaia extract
additives.details: Extracted from the bark of the soap tree (Quillaia saponaria). The tree is native to China and Peru and is commercially cultivated in southern California. Known to promote healing and reduce excessive oiliness in the skin.

additives.name: Amylase
additives.details: Derived from mould mushroom or pig pancreas.

additives.name: Invertase
additives.details: Enzyme that breaks down sucrose. Commercially derived from the fermentation of yeast.

additives.name: Lysozyme
additives.details: A naturally occuring enzyme that kills bacteria. Origin - chicken eggs.

additives.name: Polydextrose
additives.foods: Baked products, chewing gum, dairy desserts, sweets.
additives.details: Polydextrose is a low-calorie thickener that can help to replace sugars and fats.

additives.name: Polyvinylpyrrolidone
additives.details: Carriers are substances that can be used to contain another additive.

additives.name: Polyvinylpolypyrrolidone
additives.details: Carriers are substances that can be used to contain another additive.

additives.name: Oxidised starch

additives.details: Modified starches form gels when added to foods. This thickens the food without having to heat it. They can also be used to help stabilise oily foods. The starch helps to emulsify the fats and so prevent the fat separating out.

additives.warnings: Part becomes alcohol in the body.
additives.details: Used in dried egg whites to allow them to foam correctly when beaten.

additives.name: Plain caramel
additives.function: food coloring (range from dark brown to black)
additives.warnings: HACSG recommends to avoid it.
additives.foods: Beer, brown bread, buns, chocolate, biscuits, brandy, chocolate flavoured flour based confectionery, coatings, decorations, fillings and toppings, crisps, dessert mixes, doughnuts, fish and shellfish spreads, frozen desserts, glucose tablets, gravy browning, ice cream, jams, milk desserts, pancakes, pickles, sauces and dressings, soft drinks particularly cola drinks, stouts, sweets, vinegar, whisky and wines.
additives.details: Made by controlled heat treatment of sugar beet or sugar cane (with or without the presence of alkalis or acids). The caramel group of colours are the most widely used group of colours, comprising some 98% of all colours used.

additives.name: Caustic sulphite caramel
additives.warnings: See E150a
additives.details: See E150a

additives.name: Ammonia caramel
additives.warnings: See E150a
additives.details: See E150a

additives.name: Sulphite ammonia caramel
additives.warnings: See E150a
additives.details: See E150a

additives.name: Black PN; Brilliant Black BN
additives.warnings: Not recommended for consumption by children. HACSG recommends to avoid it.
additives.status: Banned in Denmark, Australia, Austria, Belgium, Canada, Finland, France, Germany, Japan, Norway, Switzerland, Sweden, USA and Norway.
additives.foods: Used in decorations and coatings, desserts, fish paste, flavoured milk drinks, ice cream, mustard, red fruit jams, sauces, savoury snacks, soft drinks, soups and sweets.
additives.details: A violet/black synthetic coal tar and azo dye.

additives.name: Ethanol
additives.details: Alcohol

additives.name: Glyceryl triacetate, triacetin
additives.foods: Baked foods and mixes, soft drinks, chewing gum and sweets.
additives.details: Helps to prevent the food it is added to from drying out.

additives.name: Propylene glycol
additives.warnings: Has been linked with fatal heart attacks, central nervous system depression, contact dermatitis.
additives.details: Helps to prevent the food it is added to from drying out.
